awd_titl_txt: URoL: Epigenetics 2: Learning the rules of dynamic epigenetic regulation
awd_abstract_narration:
In the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell, the DNA genome can be chemically modified to confer additional, so-called epigenetic, coding information. A central unanswered question in regulatory biology is how epigenetic information is decoded and used by cells as they grow and differentiate. This project aims to address that question by first developing experimental and computational strategies to predict how the genome and its epigenetic modifications are used and then testing the validity of the predictions.  The testing will be done through experiments in simple cellular systems, as well as in cells programmed to differentiate into components of the human immune system.  The results are expected to reveal regulatory ‘rules’ that can be used to engineer desirable cellular outcomes. The project will have educational impact by partnering with an existing program (Rainier Scholars, www.rainiercholars.org) to broaden participation in STEM by offering a pathway to college graduation for low-income students of color. In addition, research results from this project will be incorporated in development of course modules to teach design principles of epigenetic regulation at both participating institutions, the University of Washington and California Institute of Technology.   

Epigenetic regulation is central to all aspects of human biology. However, despite its centrality and the wealth of molecular information already collected, we still lack a predictive understanding of epigenetic control. This project combines synthetic biology, developmental biology, and computational machine learning approaches, to develop and validate predictive models of how chromatin state, sequence context, and specific regulators together establish gene expression state.  These models will provide three key benefits. First, they will provide fundamental biological insight into the architecture of eukaryotic gene regulation. Second, they will permit engineering of synthetic chromatin-based regulatory systems that provide useful functionality, including the ability to establish stable gene expression states. Such synthetic systems would enable cell-based therapies that utilize the machinery of chromatin regulation to establish, maintain, and change cellular states in response to environmental conditions, even in cells participating in immune responses and other complex processes. Third, these models will help researchers understand how eukaryotic organisms harness chromatin regulation to control cell state transitions in their development. This knowledge not only will enhance the ability to interface with the natural cell fate control circuitry, but also will reveal design principles for optimizing the function of synthetic chromatin regulatory systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A predictive understanding of the design rules that govern combinatorial gene regulation in mammalian cells would enable engineering of complex regulatory systems, paving the way for engineering more complex multicellular systems. The overarching goals of this project were developing an enhanced predictive and quantitative understanding of how chromatin state, sequence context, and chromatin regulators collectively determine gene expression levels and epigenetic stability. By combining synthetic biology, computational modeling, developmental biology, and advanced sequencing approaches, we have advanced each of the project’s core aims and uncovered new insights into the rules governing gene regulation in mammalian systems using the support from this award. 

First, we refined and optimized our Genome/Reporter interProcessing (GRiP) assay for quantifying how genomic integration sites influence gene expression. Efforts focused on adjusting reporter cassette designs—including barcode lengths, polyadenylation signals, and other sequence features—enabling more robust integration and clearer transcript mapping. Through DNA and RNA sequencing, we achieved improved resolution in determining how insertion sites and local chromatin states affect reporter expression in human cell lines. These advances set the stage for building predictive models that more accurately capture how genomic position and chromatin environment together modulate gene expression outputs.

Second, our work on understanding the combinatorial actions of chromatin regulators and the Mediator complex yielded valuable insights. We leveraged computational modeling to identify how competitive and cooperative interactions among transcription factors and Mediator subunits shape gene regulatory logic. Experiments using single-copy reporters integrated at defined genomic loci reproduced previously observed pairwise interactions between Mediator subunits, reinforcing the idea that such interactions are intrinsic features of the natural regulatory landscape. We also developed a multiplexed CRISPRi system capable of modulating Mediator subunit composition in a controlled manner. Using this approach, we have made it possible to dissect how altering Mediator components individually or in combinations influences the transcriptome, thereby illuminating fundamental design rules of combinatorial gene regulation. In parallel, we expanded a protein barcode technology to increase the number of distinct protein “signatures” that can be read out via nanopore sequencing. We also achieved key insights into DNA methylation-dependent silencing by systematically varying CpG density in synthetic promoters. This work demonstrated a direct correlation between CpG content and the kinetics of DNMT-mediated silencing. Notably, we identified a single critical CpG site that disproportionately influences silencing dynamics.

Finally, to assess whether rules derived from synthetic models apply in natural developmental contexts, we focused on T cell lineage commitment, a system that undergoes well-characterized fate transitions. By recruiting chromatin modifiers to defined elements within the Bcl11b super-enhancer, we uncovered a complex regulatory architecture in which enhancer elements and boundary sites interact to control the timing and level of gene activation. Unexpected results—such as the accelerated expression and lineage progression induced by repressing an adjacent CTCF boundary element—highlight the nuanced interplay of regulatory DNA elements and chromatin state in orchestrating proper developmental gene expression kinetics.

These accomplishments have advanced the long-term ambitions of creating predictive, quantitative models of gene regulation. By integrating synthetic and computational tools with cellular and developmental systems, we are moving toward a deeper, more mechanistic understanding of how chromatin modifications, regulatory complexes, and genomic architecture coalesce to determine gene expression outcomes. In addition, the support from this award has enabled the professional growth of many graduate and undergraduate trainees, equipping the next generation of scientists with the skills to integrate experimental, computational, and quantitative insights into gene regulation research.
